node.title: Louise's ceiling fell apart after cricket-ball-sized hail ruined her roof. A year later her home is still unliveable
node.description: More than a year after hailstones wreaked havoc on the south-east, hundreds are still awaiting repairs. Some families are still homeless; others are still carrying emotional burdens, as another storm season approaches.

node.title: Woman who allegedly escaped Adelaide CBD medi-hotel arrested after four days
node.description: A woman who allegedly escaped a medi-hotel in Adelaide's CBD via the fire escape and was wanted by police for four days has been arrested.

node.title: 'Freakish speeds': Queensland considers putting brakes on private e-scooters
node.description: Private e-scooter use has become the "wild west of the e-mobility market" and needs to be better regulated, Brisbane City Council transport chair Ryan Murphy says, ahead of a state government roundtable on e-scooter laws.

node.title: ‘Taylor’s Version’ Is the Version for the Moment
node.description: Drive and cry.

node.title: The Pandemic Prompted People to Retire Early. Will They Return to Work?
node.description: Workers who retired because of Covid-19 are being enticed to return.

node.title: It’s All About the Guns
node.description: Kyle Rittenhouse’s semiautomatic rifle endangered everybody around him —  and himself.

node.title: Boris Johnson Battered in Parliament as Scandal Puts Him on Defense
node.description: Reversals and broken promises have eroded his party’s lead in the polls, and the prime minister faces a low-grade mutiny from Conservatives angry over a proposal to limit their options for extra income.

node.title: Hackers With Links to Iran's Government Targeting U.S. With Ransomware Attacks
node.description: Though ransomware attacks have become a widely known issue, most of the major attacks have been connected to Russian hacker groups rather than Iranian hackers.

node.title: White House: 'Ironic' That GOP Condemns Members for Infrastructure Vote but Not Paul Gosar
node.description: Most of the Republican caucus has been tight-lipped on Gosar's anime video depicting him killing Democratic Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.

node.title: COVID Relief Cash Funded Florida Drug Dealers Day to Day Operations: Police
node.description: Three "documented gang members" were recently arrested for obtaining small business loans worth about $50,000.

node.title: Get up to speed on all the COVID-19 updates from across Australia
node.description: Stay across all the latest coronavirus updates as they happen. Follow live.

node.title: Visions of a U.S. Computer Chip Boom Have Cities Hustling
node.description: Many local governments see a silver lining in the shortage of semiconductor chips that has contributed to a slowdown in the global economy.

node.title: Quentin Tarantino Sued By Miramax Over Director's Plans to Auction 'Pulp Fiction' NFTs
node.description: The film studio is suing the director over concerns of copyright infringement and contract violation.

node.title: Shell, BP Among Bidders for New Oil, Gas Leases Across 2,700 Square Miles of Gulf of Mexico
node.description: The sale of thousands of square miles of land has received criticism from environmentalists and climate experts who say Biden is ignoring climate promises.

node.title: Is Australia facing an exodus of international students that could undercut its global position?
node.description: Australia's international education sector is facing a critical time as it tries to recover from COVID border closures and keep its footing in the global market.

node.title: Floods to cost farmers millions, but Forbes is spared the worst of it
node.description: The NSW central west town of Forbes appears to have escaped major flooding, but farmers in the region say they're counting losses into the millions of dollars.

node.title: Naomi Osaka expresses concern for Chinese tennis star Peng Shuai
node.description: Peng, who was once ranked No. 1 in women's doubles, accused a former Chinese state official of sexual assault.

node.title: U.S., Japan Agree to Resolve Trump-Era Tariffs, Discuss 'Unfair Practices' in Trade
node.description: A partnership was announced earlier this week that will work on a "Japan-U.S. common global agenda" for trade and cooperation in the Indo-Pacific region.

node.title: South Dakota Gov. Kristi Noem's Daughter Says Scrutiny Has Destroyed Real Estate Business
node.description: Kassidy Peters said she will be leaving the real estate appraiser business after a legislative inquiry into her license.

node.title: U.S. Offers Billions to Drugmakers to Ramp up COVID Vaccine Supplies Locally, Abroad
node.description: "The U.S. needs to make sure these companies, which they funded, are prioritizing public health rather than profits," said advocacy manager Robbie Silverman.

node.title: Price rise puts Whangārei's Ōruku Landing project at risk
node.description: New report indicates the proposed waterfront development could cost ratepayers an additional $13m.

node.title: Two men convicted of killing Malcolm X will be exonerated
node.description: Both men spent over two decades in prison for a crime they vowed they did not commit.

node.title: Can This Covid Winter Be Merry and Bright? We Asked the Experts.
node.description: Three experts respond to questions from readers about how to navigate another Covid winter.

node.title: I’m 87, Triple Vaxxed and Living My Life Again
node.description: My life expectancy is six more years. Covid-19 can’t prevent me from enjoying the time I have left.

node.title: The Supply-Chain Crisis Is a Labor Crisis
node.description: Governments around the world have failed transport workers. But it’s not too late to help them.

node.title: Who are Muhammad Aziz and Khalil Islam, the exonerated men?
node.description: In 1965, the two men were members of the Nation of Islam militia, working at the Harlem mosque that Malcolm X led before breaking with the group.

node.title: Idaho Lawmaker Is Censured for Doxxing Intern Who Reported Rape
node.description: Priscilla Giddings, an Idaho state representative, shared a student intern’s personal information after the teenager accused another lawmaker of rape.

node.title: The F.D.A. could authorize Moderna boosters for all adults as early as this week.
node.description: If the C.D.C. also signs off on broad booster requests by Moderna and Pfizer, every adult who was fully vaccinated with them at least six months ago would not only be eligible, but could choose which type of booster shot to get.

node.title: How the Belarus Standoff Is Unlike Recent Migrant Crises
node.description: The images at the Belarus-Poland border look familiar, but this emergency has little in common with previous waves of people from Syria, Myanmar and Afghanistan.

node.title: 2 Bodies Found Decade After Mine Explosion Killed 29, 'Too Dangerous' to Retrieve Them
node.description: Methane levels where the bodies were discovered are still high. Police are unable to retrieve the remains because the mine is not safe to enter.

node.title: AOC Ahead of Vote on Gosar Censure: 'What's so Hard About Saying 'This is Wrong?''
node.description: U.S. Representative Paul Gosar faces censure over an animated video he tweeted depicting himself killing his Democratic colleague.

node.title: Trump Ally Steve Bannon Pleads Not Guilty in Battle Over January 6 Probe
node.description: Bannon's plea isn't entirely surprising because when he turned himself in he said we're "taking down the Biden regime."

node.title: Bannon to plead not guilty to contempt of Congress charges
node.description: In the filing, Bannon said he "freely and voluntarily" waives his "right on the indictment and my right to have it read to me in open court."

node.title: No Surprises as Arozarena and India Win Rookie of the Year Awards
node.description: Tampa Bay’s Randy Arozarena and Cincinnati’s Jonathan India stood out in a deep rookie class for both leagues.

node.title: The Netflix documentary series ‘Who Killed Malcolm X?’ spurred prosecutors to review the trial.
node.description: Popular documentary series on television also led to indictments against the real estate mogul Robert Durst and the singer R. Kelly.

node.title: A couple convicted of stealing Covid funds is on the run, the F.B.I. says.
node.description: Richard Ayvazyan and his wife, Marietta Terabelian, cut their monitoring bracelets and fled in August, the agency said. On Monday, they were sentenced in absentia.

node.title: South Dakota Governor 'Absolutely' Credits Lack of Lockdowns With Overdose Death Decline
node.description: America saw record-high overdose deaths in the first year of the pandemic, which many experts attribute to isolation, job loss and lack of access to treatment.

node.title: Washington's High Court to Decide Redistricting Lines After Committee Misses Deadline
node.description: For the first time since 1990, the committee charged with redrawing Washington state's legislative districts missed their deadline to complete the map.

node.title: Woman Rejects Attempted Kiss From O.J. Simpson in Viral Video
node.description: "She dodged that kiss like he was dodging that case," one commenter said of the former Heisman Trophy-winning runningback.

node.title: US Capitol rioter 'QAnon Shaman' sentenced to over three years in prison
node.description: Jacob Chansley, the so-called "Qanon Shaman", is sentenced to almost three and a half years in prison for his role in the US Capitol riots in January 6.

node.title: 'It's now your turn to be uncomfortable': Australian beer's moment of reckoning
node.description: Amid reports of harassment and abuse in the Australian beer industry, a group of female leaders has banded together to force change.

node.title: Noel loves vintage cars — but his EV now takes pride of place in his garage
node.description: A growing number of Australian car lovers are turning to electric vehicles — but experts and industry figures say more can be done to encourage uptake and lower prices.

node.title: 'Rollercoaster of emotions' on discovery of bodies in Pike River mine
node.description: Footage showing bodies inside the Pike River mine was what loved ones of the 29 men killed in the disaster had been waiting for - but it was coupled with knowledge that none would be recovered.

node.title: Lawsuit claims construction triggered deadly condo collapse
node.description: "The collapse was entirely preventable," says a lawsuit filed on behalf of Champlain Towers South victims and family members.

node.title: Roger Federer to Miss Australian Open and All but Rules Out Wimbledon
node.description: Recovering from his fourth knee operation, Federer, at 40, has no illusions about winning a 21st major title. He wants to return for different reasons.

node.title: U.K. Bombing Suspect 'Committed Christian,' Police Say He Acted Alone, Planned for Months
node.description: Emad Al Swealmeen had been making "relevant purchases" for an explosive device since at least April, police said.

node.title: Waikato biggest loser as doctors, nurses and midwives stood down across country
node.description: District health boards are operating without 470 nurses because they have not been vaccinated.

node.title: Money moves you can use to help ward off inflation

node.title: This is who scholars believe really killed Malcolm X.

node.title: ‘Then I Felt a Tap on My Shoulder’
node.description: A sad moment as dusk falls, from this week's Metropolitan Diary

node.title: New Delhi Considers Lockdown, But Not for COVID, as Smog Chokes City of 20 Million
node.description: Smog covered the Indian city of New Delhi where air particles were seven times higher than what the World Health Organization deemed as safe levels.

node.title: COVID Lockdowns Saw Global Increase in Helpline Calls About Loneliness, Suicide: Report
node.description: Researchers determined that the number of calls was highest at six weeks into the pandemic in 2020, and 35 percent higher than the same period in the year prior.

node.title: TikToker Who Called out of Work Sick Caught on Camera at NBA Game in Viral Video
node.description: "I don't believe a boss should be mad over that. Our life doesn't belong to any company," one comment read.

node.title: Viral Video Showing a Surveillance Camera Visible in Fitting Room Mirror Sparks Debate
node.description: "Wow I'm so mad, I literally noticed when I was putting my clothes back on," reads the video's text overlay.

node.title: Endangered curlews feed here at the end of their epic migration, but a retirement village may be built next door
node.description: Critics say a plan to develop a retirement village next to endangered bird habitat will further jeopardise a species in decline, but the developers say they're being made scapegoats.

node.title: Borders are reopening and COVID is coming. What can Tasmanians expect?
node.description: It's a message Tasmania's Premier Peter Gutwein has been driving home: COVID will enter Tasmania when borders open next month. So when and where is the state likely to have an outbreak?

node.title: Sam is trapped in Katherine as COVID cases grow. And he's not the only one
node.description: As Katherine grapples with the NT's biggest COVID-19 outbreak to date, Sam Ashley has been sleeping on a patch of grass near the river.

node.title: Private security could soon guard secretive naval communications base instead of AFP
node.description: One of the country's most secretive and important military facilities, which helps support Australian and US naval operations, could soon be guarded by private security personnel, rather than federal police.

node.title: Childcare 'crisis situation' as vaccine mandates force some workers out
node.description: Childcare centre operators say fee hikes at some centres are inevitable as mandates for COVID-19 vaccinations around the country force them to terminate some staff and put others on leave.

node.title: Cash hoarders stuffed record amounts under mattresses during pandemic
node.description: Before the pandemic, there were about $80 billion in notes circulating in Australia. Now there's $100 billion — but it's not in cash registers.

node.title: Kate's abusive ex racked up almost $86k of debt in her name. This is how she got help
node.description: Shortly after domestic violence survivor Kate left her husband, the banks started chasing her to repay debts in her name. It was not until she got help from a lawyer and financial counsellor that she realised there was a way out.

node.title: The cleanest jet fuel has an explosive history. Would you board a hydrogen plane?
node.description: As the world looks for new ways to combat climate change, hydrogen has emerged as a potential saviour for polluting industries like aviation. But will it work?

node.title: Why and how books get challenged
node.description: Parents have the right to petition school boards to remove books — but censorship is also a First Amendment issue.

node.title: Park Avenue Armory Announces Futuristic New Season

node.title: CEO of World's Largest Crypto Exchange Says It's Time the Industry Gets Some Rules
node.description: Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao feels it is "the right time" to introduce regulations into the cryptocurrency industry.

node.title: Gas Trade Group Calls Biden's Demand for Probe a 'Distraction' Amid Misconduct Accusations
node.description: The president asked the FTC to investigate whether Americans are paying more for gas "because of anti-competitive or otherwise potentially illegal conduct."

node.title: Starbucks Employee Slammed for Filming 'Racist' TikTok While on the Job in Viral Clip
node.description: According to the company's official guidelines, "You must not promote any political or personal views or beliefs on or around Starbucks premises."

node.title: Court only avenue for alleged victims to prove claims against nurse James Griffin
node.description: The Tasmanian Health Service has not admitted to the abuse by Launceston nurse James Griffin claimed by the three plaintiffs, as court documents detail new information about concerns raised at the hospital about his conduct.

node.title: William Tyrrell strategy 'lacking in early days' but valuable lessons helped find Cleo Smith, expert says
node.description: A leading criminologist says some of the reasons William Tyrrell hasn't been found in seven years helped police in Western Australia locate missing girl Cleo Smith after 18 days.

node.title: Disney Cruise Line will require all passengers ages 5 and older to be fully vaccinated.
node.description: The mandate will go into effect on Jan. 13 and will apply to sailings both in the United States and abroad.

node.title: New Year’s Eve Will Return to Times Square for Vaccinated Guests
node.description: The event will return at “full strength” after pared-back festivities last year, Mayor Bill de Blasio said. People will have to show proof that they are fully vaccinated to attend.

node.title: The White House estimates nearly 10 percent of younger children have gotten a first shot.
node.description: Last week alone, 1.7 million young children were vaccinated, about double the previous week, a White House official said.

node.title: Young U.S. Men's Soccer Team Sees Path Back to World Cup After Missing Last One
node.description: After not qualifying for the 2018 FIFA World Cup, the U.S. men's national team needs three more home wins to qualify for the 2022 event.

node.title: In New Rules, U.S. Catholic Bishops Sidestep Direct Answer on Who Is Allowed Communion
node.description: The proposed document has generated controversy since the bishops' assembly first decided to begin drafting it in June.

node.title: Rittenhouse Judge Says He Allowed Defendant to Pick Jurors to Protect 'Optics'
node.description: Judge Bruce Schroeder said ever since he tried a case with "bad optics" around picking which jurors would deliberate, he has had the "almost universal policy."

node.title: 'It hurts, but it's a good thing': Human remains discovered in Pike River mine
node.description: A turbulent mix of emotions are being felt as - just two days shy of the 11th anniversary of the Pike River mine disaster- human remains have been discovered.

node.title: ‘The Antelope Party’ Review: Friendship Is Magic, With Exceptions

node.title: They Love Crypto. They’re Trying to Buy the Constitution.

node.title: A new witness supports the original alibi of one of the wrongfully convicted men.

node.title: A timeline of major events in the case since Malcolm X’s death.
node.description: Uncertainties about who really killed Malcolm X have plagued the case since 1965.

node.title: ICC to study Afghanistan situation

node.title: Greece to Put Aid Workers Who Helped Migrants on Trial on Espionage Charges
node.description: The country’s conservative government is toughening its stance on migration and on groups working with migrants, aligning itself with a hardening climate across Europe.

node.title: Popular European Destinations That Unvaccinated People Can and Can't Travel To
node.description: Several European countries have placed travel restrictions on unvaccinated travelers from the United States.

node.title: Why Smallpox Is so Dangerous As Vials Found in Pennsylvania
node.description: The FBI and CDC are investigating after 15 vials labeled "smallpox" were discovered at a lab outside Philadelphia.

node.title: Radioactive Water From Fukushima Plant Would Have Small Environmental Impact: Operator
node.description: Japan planned to release treated radioactive water in the spring of 2023 after data simulation said there's little environmental impact. Experts aren't so sure.

node.title: Bear Cub Plays in Snow for the First Time in Adorable Video
node.description: After being found in a yard of a home in May, Aina romped around with Sulo "The bearman" Karjalainen.

node.title: Watch NHL Player Kevin Hayes Honor Late Brother Jimmy After Scoring First Goal of Season
node.description: After scoring the goal, Hayes said that he planned to give the puck to his brother's son, Beau.

node.description: Defense attorneys argued that the presence of high-profile visitors, such as civil rights leaders, could alter the jury's verdict.

node.title: Monarch Butterflies Return to California in Large Numbers After Last Year's Historic Low
node.description: Pacific Grove in California is one of the many areas the butterflies are expected to land during the winter.

node.title: Justus Rosenberg, Beloved Professor With a Heroic Past, Dies at 100
node.description: As a teenager, he helped provide safe passage to artists and intellectuals out of Vichy France. He went on to teach literature at Bard College for six decades.

node.title: Philip Margo of the Tokens, Who Sang of a Snoozing Lion, Dies at 79
node.description: His baritone contributed to the 1961 hit “The Lion Sleeps Tonight,” which became one of the most recognizable American pop songs ever.

node.title: The Secret to Great Online Communities
node.description: Our online experiences are shaped by the people who run our favorite Facebook group or Reddit forum.

node.title: Oklahoma Governor and Pentagon Standoff Over Vaccines Intensifies
node.description: The state says its National Guard members don’t need to get vaccinated. Pentagon officials say a failure to follow “valid medical readiness requirements” could “jeopardize” the status of troops.

node.title: Sudanese forces kill 10 protesting the country’s recent coup, medics report.
node.description: The violence is shadowing Secretary of State Antony Blinken’s visit to Africa.

node.title: Steve Bannon's Lawyer Decries 'Vindictive' Prosecution by Jan 6. Committee
node.description: David Schoen has taken aim at the congressional committee examining the events that led up to the U.S. Capitol riots.

node.title: Lobster Harvesting Ban Reinstated Off Maine Coast in Effort to Protect Rare Whales
node.description: A U.S. appeals court ruled that the government's role is "assuring the right whales are protected from a critical risk of death."

node.title: In the suburbs of Melbourne, Logan felt a void in his life. He filled it with fire
node.description: Leaving the beaches of Samoa for the suburbs of Melbourne created a void in Logan’s life, one that could only be filled by returning to his roots.

node.title: With a federal election looming, the Great Resignation presents politicians with big opportunities
node.description: For employers trying to keep and attract the best staff, COVID-inspired upheaval in Australia's job market presents enormous challenges. For politicians facing a looming election, it presents opportunities, writes David Speers.

node.title: The Legacy of Mattress Cash Fires

node.title: Germany Weighs 5 Years in Prison for Forging COVID Test Results, Vaccine Documents
